generation: Another week flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and the front window was covered in boxes. We might receive the keys at closing, which is exciting. If everything goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 a.m. last night watching movies with Bethany. There's been a lot of movie-watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched "Gigli," and it was just as bad as the media said, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer television used to be a dead zone filled with reruns, but now there are two great new shows that I have been watching religiously for the past week. One of them is "Blow Out," which astonishingly lacks any gay presence despite its flamboyant concept. In this show, hairstylist Jonathan Antin aims to expand his immensely popular West Hollywood salon by opening a second location in Beverly Hills. Normally, I wouldn't care, but as I was channel surfing, I glimpsed Jonathan, with his intriguing blend of narcissism and dullness, surveying an empty space on Rodeo Drive. He declared, "I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world!" Instantly, I was captivated. Not since Rocco have I found someone so compelling to watch on TV.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendinitis, right under my shoulder blade. When I move my arm too much, especially using a computer mouse, it causes a lot of pain. I can't move it much now because I was updating my website and working on other online tasks. I can barely muster the strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep worsens my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but I'll get better. My mom's surgery went okay. Some of her eyesight has returned, and she can now see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Other than that, she's still quite blind. Hopefully, she'll fully regain her vision soon.

Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and quickly realized how the simplest tasks can become quite an ordeal. Remarkably, I discovered how sweet total strangers can be, just because they feel like it. Trust me, it wasn't because they were trying for anything more; I had kid drool on me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit. Plus, I'm pretty sure I won't be bathing for a while, so there wasn't even an olfactory incentive! Currently, I'm doing two things: composing a post and watching the collected No Doubt videos, both while sitting at my desk in my room.

It's 11:14 PM MST, and I'm sitting in my bedroom repairing the personal computer of my job's personnel director. I don't mind doing it, but I sometimes wonder how often I end up fixing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm happy to help people this way, but where do you draw the line to avoid being taken advantage of? In the past couple of weeks, I've stayed up late reading and such, so I was looking forward to going to bed early—until I realized it would be more prudent to return this computer to its owner. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So, I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation in the "is this a date?" saga. After the weird lunch, my confidence was shaken, and I realized I forgot to share an important part of the story. Before Pat showed up for lunch, Dustin started talking about what a nice guy Pat is and how he’s trying to find a girlfriend for him. I was listening, nodding, and realizing that we were talking more about finding Dustin’s best friend a girl than discussing whatever you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and silently asked myself: Am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this what happens now?

I would like everyone to think before they act. Specifically, I'd like each person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning and commit to thoughtful behavior all day. If someone isn't prepared to do so, I wish they'd just stay in bed. I'm really tired of dealing with foolishness. I'm not claiming to be the smartest person around, but I'm not talking about anything that requires a lot of intelligence, so I think it's fair to criticize the exceptionally thoughtless. Let's see if I can keep this rant focused on a few specific types, and we can save the rest for another day. Sound good? Great.

Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. Bush is indeed stimulating the economy, but in an ineffective manner. Robert Rubin, speaking to NPR's Marketplace, mentioned that Bush could have achieved similar stimulus effects without the burden of long-term debt by enacting different, temporary tax cuts that would aid low- and middle-income individuals. Ah, Robert Rubin—the mere mention of his name delights us. Quick: can you name a Bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side who has Rubin's gravitas? Still thinking? It’ll come to you... 2. We can't entrust Republicans with control only in wartime, as they've cleverly invented an endless global 'war on terrorism.'

Haven't updated in a while, but not much to say. Went to the cove to see Supernothing; they were good as usual. Got to chill with Tiago. On Saturday, went to work and then out with Joe and Rach; met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Came home at about 11:45 and woke up the next morning at 6:45 for a meet. Got there a little late, but it's all good. I did my full routine on the floor and didn't fall. Finished second in floor and vault, third on beam, with a 29.45 all-around score, which isn't bad since my meets improve as the season progresses.

Have you ever had one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like you're in math class, bored out of your mind, and you wonder how your brain comprehends math? Then you realize you're in math class and question why. Suddenly, you recognize how incredible existing is. Yet it hits you—going off on this random train of thought feels incredibly aimless. Has that happened to you? I can't stand it. You know what else bothers me? Block schedules. Who thought of that idea? Clearly, enduring a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is borderline cruel and unusual punishment.

I think that Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow never to lay my hands on that darn iron (not a hot one, but the piece in the game) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the game—or maybe I let him win because he's leaving in a few hours, and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story goes, it can't compare to this Texas-sized headache I have at the moment. I've taken some Aleve, and I must say they're doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation.

Today's been a long day; we drove home from Indiana. I'll need to be selective about what I write since I could easily go on for quite some time, and I don’t have enough energy. First of all, I must say that camp was incredible, even better than I had anticipated. God has been working in my life lately, and it's amazing. I feel like I've turned over a new leaf. Back to the beginning, we arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. We went to the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watched movies.

Today is the last day of my summer vacation, and I have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but I'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think of for not wanting to go back to school. This is going to be a whole new experience for me. As a perfectionist, I love excelling at everything I do, but starting new things is challenging. I hate being a pawn (like I told Cassie: 'I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and I hate not knowing what's going on.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had forewarned, as early as 1996, about the looming threat of a "third Islamic state" emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had forecasted this serious concern in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie raises a pertinent question when he asks, does discovering that Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, authored these warnings make them more credible? Or do you conclude that because Rajeswar sounded this alarm, he is a closet communalist who should not continue as Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

Attitude: Bored; Mood: Indifferent. Looking forward to tonight—it's been a long, hard day in the trenches here, folks. Almost no time to write anything for you readers. However, it's good to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking up the reins herself, making an appearance, and discussing things. Not much to say about yesterday; it was Shakespeare on the Green—a lovely play. Unfortunately, I had to leave before the final curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully, someday I'll see an entire Shakespeare play. But I digress. Akcron is right about the shower problems; it’s frustrating. The humor, though, in seeing someone struggling can be surprisingly entertaining.

Suddenly, over the past two days, I've been overwhelmed with intense exhaustion—utterly bone-tired. Last evening, I went home and immediately fell asleep, only waking when my mother called around eight-thirty. Upon waking, it was completely dark; I hadn't turned on the lights, so I couldn't tell the time or date for a few seconds. It was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. I wonder why I'm feeling so drained. The weather is pleasant this morning; it was drizzling when I arrived. However, I've heard it’s been raining in Calcutta for the last three days.

Last night was the worst. I discarded the sweater I was knitting. I only had about 14 inches completed. I lost around $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But I ended up with too many stitches by the time I reached the armholes, and the mohair was tangling, making frogging (ripping out rows) difficult. The yarn broke often. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just gloomily ripped and listened to season two of Sex and the City (thanks to the library!). Eventually, I got fed up and threw it away. I suppose I learned a lot while attempting to make this sweater.

Last night in class, we discussed that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter deals with “implacement,” while the second focuses on “displacement.” In the first chapter, Casey highlights that our contemporary world revolves around time as the central force: we feel we are running out of time, saving time, and being just in time. He argues that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded community. (This is a very rough summary—just a disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading to truly captivate me.

Whatever they put into freeze pops to achieve those vibrant colors should come with a warning: may cause unexpected adventures. And although laughing is healthy, it makes one wonder if we would have found ourselves climbing that fire escape to drink beer in the strong wind had we not indulged earlier. As we stood in a doorway of a bar sadly closed for business, we paused to sift through an office-supplies catalog that had arrived by mail. Fortunately, we did. Who would have imagined that within these pages were the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not I. Here are just a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, receive a stunt kite; buy 30 lever arch files, receive a barbecue.

Currently listening to: "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero. And now my post... Senate Republicans, hands up—who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn't. Well, okay—I did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans, annoyed that Democrats wouldn't nominate four of Bush's controversial justices, who were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day event. Never mind the fact that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush's judicial nominees—that's not good enough for the Republicans who seem to believe they have a huge mandate for this kind of behavior.

This was a good weekend. I enjoyed nature, listened to a lot of Nevermore (something I should have started doing much earlier), and read extensively. I finished three books: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future USA, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced, and altogether convincing, I must confess that I failed to come away with any really significant impressions about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched—it's a good book, but not a great one, I guess.

After the first week back from practicum, overcoming the challenges was tough, but only in the second week has the fog truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma was an overlooked issue now gaining attention. I was affected, but meeting with the course coordinator allowed me to unburden myself, thus preventing another individual from being placed in a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I encountered a fellow classmate who was determined to warn the student assigned to her former school about its flaws. I calmed her down, suggesting that we approach the administrator first to address the concerns.

Things can get incredibly busy here, but there's always time for stress-relieving activities. I've found that I'm not very good at 8-ball and ping pong! Rick, the Canadian, beats me regularly. We have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, so there's always time for a quick round. Last night, I participated in an 8-ball tournament at the hot spot, our recreation tent complete with a popcorn machine, numerous TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, dartboard, and always the ping pong table. I was doing well in my one entire game until I scratched on the eight ball. I still had a good time, especially with the two Dutch soldiers joining the tournament.

In the fall of 1974, I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to navigate the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I wasn’t then, nor am I now, a math person. Math has always been a challenge for me. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and opened the door; no one was there. Frustrated, I returned to my studies, just as a little glimmer of understanding emerged. The doorbell rang again, disrupting my breakthrough. Once more, no one was there—a perfect prank for a struggling math student.

This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday to Thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade-level team. These are important considerations as I spend hours preparing my room for this year. Had I known I was going to move prior to the end of the school year, I would have discarded many books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So, this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging extensively. I have to thank my teammate Jill for helping with everything. She was still teaching this month, in my old room. She and her wonderful students moved almost my entire room for me!

You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if I never carried your child, even if I was never married to you, even if I was never an official pair with you, I loved you immensely, and to this day, the feeling echoes through my heart. I will forever be reminded of those few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach, or a kiss under the rain. Whenever I feel a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me and still remains.

I feel uncomfortable. Investigative reporting doesn't feel right to me. To rephrase, the article I'm working on and its consequences aren't something I'm entirely comfortable with. Perhaps it's because I don't fully believe in it, which prevents me from truly understanding its essence. The angst behind it. The full-on passion required to question. I grew up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They punish you for that. They imprison you with internal security acts. I'm not used to this freedom of speech... not accustomed to questioning openly. Sure, I am not the easiest person to get along with.

Yesterday, my colleagues and I went on an outing to Guintubdan, La Carlota. It was a first-time experience for most of us. We embarked on a 30-minute trek to the falls, leaving us breathless, but we persevered. The water was icy, and you could feel your body going numb from the chill. We stayed for less than an hour before heading to a nearby waterfall—another 30-minute trek. The trip was worth it, as the falls presented a calming and breathtaking scene. It felt as if you could hear yourself becoming one with nature. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth, as the cold air and water lulled us into serenity.

I'm sure my sisters are drunk. Today was Pride in San Diego. I know them, and when it's time to drink, it's time to drink. The desire to drink is the one thing I didn't inherit from the Buenviajes. There are few occasions when I don't mind drinking, but they are very rare. We have a month left before Ed leaves. I think it's starting to sink in with Ed and with all of us. I realized it a long time ago. I just hope Ed will be here for Bailey's surgery. We've been monitoring his swelling, and there's definitely quite a bit.

On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, thinking the Easter egg hunt would start at 11 a.m., but it had actually been on Friday. Thankfully, I had brought a bag of eggs just in case. Connor had a great time finding eggs in the park. On Sunday morning, he was thrilled to find that the Easter Bunny had visited. There's nothing better than seeing the excitement on your child's face. After the egg hunt, we all attended church. Although the 'Easter Bunny' is fun, we ensure our kids understand the true meaning of the holidays. This was Megan's first Easter, and she looked adorable in her jean dress and stockings.

Friday, November 22, 2002. Woohoo, my boots are at the house! I accidentally had them delivered there instead of to work, so now I have to wait another four hours to get them. Argh! These are the face boots and Tredair flame boots. I rock! Somehow, I managed to get a flat tire. Luckily, I'm at work, so the guys are going to inflate it for me and make sure it holds air. If not, they'll change the tire and put the spare on. Thankfully, my spare is full-sized. I might buy a new tire tonight. Woohoo! Hamad Tire, here I come! I thought I had found another VW.

I know in a previous post I defended parents, almost siding with them, but I've had a change of heart. Parents often assume they know us so well, even thinking they can read our emotions. The truth is, they can't. Parents really don't understand us. For example, when I head upstairs after arguing with Nicole about Kelli, like I did a few minutes ago, they often ask what's wrong. Honestly, sometimes I wish they'd just leave it alone. I shouldn't have to explain everything to them. Here's the situation with Nicole and Kelli: they really don't get along. At all.

Music for the day: 94.7 FM. Almost didn't make it to work on time. There was a huge accident at 14th and Constitution, causing major traffic issues in Virginia. Luckily, I managed to skillfully maneuver my car from the far left lane to the far right and got onto Route 50. This probably doesn't mean much unless you live around here... so never mind. Basically, I'm just happy to be sitting here instead of still being stuck in my car. Yesterday, Sara decided to Google me, and to my surprise, the email I sent to Ivan Maisel on ESPN.com was published online! I had no idea; I didn't think it was my best argument, but I guess someone else did.

Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban was absolutely brilliant! I went to see it right after school on Friday. Yes, that's right, I saw it on opening day! (Thanks, Mike, for the ticket.) Daniel Radcliffe, aka Harry Potter, has grown up so fast, and he is so cute! Malfoy too, haha. The movie was great; I give it 4 1/2 stars because they left out some important details. Overall, the movie was good. I didn't really dress up for the movie, but I wore a Ravenclaw tie even though I like Gryffindors better. I might go see the movie again in about two more weeks.

Attempt #2 with pears and peanut butter. I have firmer pears this time and my own jar of peanut butter, which I can dip the pears into. However, it's still crunchy peanut butter, not smooth, and I definitely think it makes a difference. I am a bit surprised, as I thought this was a healthy snack, but I just noticed that per fifth of a jar (ours are much smaller), there are 614 calories per 100g! I've just returned from an evening out at my old music teacher and friend's house. Yes, I know—I missed it for that, but I taped it! I've also discovered they are showing repeats of series 9 every morning at 9:55. It was good seeing my friend—strange, but good.

Some people are quick to connect this dot: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited to monitor the election by the State Department. The observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a U.S. presidential election. Meanwhile, a group of congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, has petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida for this year's presidential election. I humbly disagree. Based on the available information, the OSCE seems to be coming here to learn from the U.S. election process, not to oversee it, contrary to the original partisan call for U.N. involvement.

My foul mood has lifted. The upcoming period and forgetting to take Prozac until late resulted in a very sad, tearful Kristin. But a surprise visit from my boyfriend, an ice cream sundae, and holding his hand after a terrifying dream where people began shooting at a news bureau brightened my spirits. Plus, I don't have to work this morning—la la la—but I do need to call a man at KMIZ to get his rate card. Tonight, I get to see two of my best friends, Amy and Kate, hopefully with time to study in between. Tomorrow, I might see someone I haven't seen in quite a while for our WW date.

A lot has been going on with me. Debbie fought with me over which china I was allowed to use. I mean, really, do you need to bring out enough expensive china to feed an entire choir? She had dishes galore—saucers, teapots, coffee cups, wine goblets, water glasses, seven different types of forks and spoons, dinner plates, salad plates, dessert plates, soup bowls, side bowls. I was overwhelmed! Then, she yelled at me for eating appetizers while the turkey was cooking. I insisted I would eat, trust me! After that, it was off to the hospital with my father.

GOP gets reprimanded as Jacksonville naturalization ceremonies are relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy. The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville proceeded as expected, with nearly 200 attendees becoming new Americans. Just before the new citizens departed the June 29 event, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in encouraged them to visit a voter registration table—a common feature at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: Republican volunteers were distributing forms, with the party affiliation box pre-checked to register all new voters as GOP members. This raised suspicion for Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

Hello everyone,

I have some good news to share. Starting this coming Monday, I will be stepping into the role of project leader for my team. My current project leader is heading onsite the day after tomorrow, which is the reason for this transition. I will be coordinating with two onsite coordinators and eight team members. Right now, I am focused on knowledge transfer plans as another project team of eight will assist us in the next release since it's going to be significant. On Monday, a BS7799 security audit will take place at Chennai's Infosys; many things need fine-tuning at this stage. I'm hopeful I'll handle all responsibilities smoothly. Let's see.

Bye for now.

Cheers,
Kavitha

Although it's not technically playing hooky, I've been saving up substitute days and decided to use one today, Wednesday the 10th in Japan (the post time reflects the U.S. date, so it’s technically incorrect), allowing me to relax for a couple of days. There's nothing like 48 hours of daydreaming to rejuvenate one's creative energy. For a foreigner, I have it good, and my timing was fortunate too. The illustration work is the icing on the cake. I’d probably complain more if this opportunity hadn’t fallen into my lap. I know I'm being taken advantage of, though; I'm not oblivious to that. Feeling hungry now. Might grab some Mexican food at Speak Easy, the 'American style' diner across the street from the post office in my little prefecture.

I have always prided myself on making anyone who frequents Casa Pescatore feel as comfortable as possible. I want them to feel at home, just as they would in their own prospective residence. Yesterday, I hope I succeeded. The masses gathered on Perry Ave, with what many consider 'extreme prejudice.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu came over with a large pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, the food I had prepared was ready, and the bells were ringing like crazy. Before I could blink, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, and that made me smile. I missed him so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along, who is expecting, and it's the closest I could get to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps it could have been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've been somewhat hesitant to engage in some of these discussions, especially those involving flags. However, since I initiated it (the topic, not the flag-burning), I suppose it's important to comment. Firstly, I believe the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely absurd. The moment you start granting a symbol—any symbol—that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small yet significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently fickle; they don't inherently represent anything. It's what they are perceived to mean or what they are made to represent that's important.

Prom is tomorrow... I hope it’s going to be fun. That's all I ask. Rob arrives on May 14th... Yeah, just three weeks from today... Oh god, I think I’m giving myself an ulcer thinking about it. But I am so excited to see him, scared too, yes, but very excited. The Leafs played last night, but because Calgary was playing at the same time and I am out on the west coast, I had to watch the Calgary game, not the Leafs game. It's alright, I guess, considering my Leafs lost, and that makes me sad. But Philly is a good team, so I still have bragging rights. They made it further than the Canucks! Today is a crazy day...

I have yet to see what my blog will actually look like, but apparently, this is the place to start. I'm not quite sure what will happen here, whether I'll take to it, but since I spend so much time in front of a computer, I might as well make proper use of my time and post all these bits of craziness that stumble around in my head. I was inspired by a blogger (whom I never met in person), who managed to keep us up to date in the most intimate fashion about her day-to-day existence, and entertained at the same time.

1. Everyone is obsessed with a movie or series of movies. What's yours? The Evil Dead series... if it wasn't obvious. (I have one of the largest collections of memorabilia from that series ever.) 2. Can you play an instrument? What is it? Bass guitar, oh yes, I rock out. 3. Biggest money-wasting vice? Either my compulsive buying of DVDs or any new technology. 4. Do you have any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? No, no, though I must organize the bills in my wallet from least to greatest at all times. 5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? Because I said so.

Hello, I watched "Troy" with my family tonight, but I wasn't impressed. I'm too tired for specifics, but it had potential. However, too much energy went into the magnificent set design, and not enough into creating a cohesive tone and theme. It retold the story but wasn't particularly gripping, and I didn't feel like I gained anything from it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, I thought the score was poor and essentially a knock-off of "Gladiator." In "Gladiator," the background music of a moaning woman worked well because it complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.

Urllink PulpFiction 1.0, from the creators at Freshly Squeezed Software, is the latest atom/RDF/RSS reader on the scene. It boasts many appealing native app features. However, it's important to mention that it isn't free, reflecting a recurring 'hot topic' online. Users can explore it with a 15-day trial before deciding to purchase it for $25. An outstanding feature is how each post acts as an independent entity, allowing users to move, store, label, and delete them. This flexibility can delight those tracking news. Additionally, it offers the capability to import and export OPML, as expected.

Today, I miss my sister terribly—it feels strange not to have her around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though she was here for only a week, she made her presence felt, and I mean that in a good way. Creating the scrapbook for our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories of last week. Maybe it's the thought of not seeing her for quite a while, with her going to Bristol in September/October. She represented a deeper connection to my family back home. Oh, how I miss them all. Tomorrow marks the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?

Ever had one of those days when you just can't figure anything out? No? Then you should probably skip the rest of this, as it might not make sense to you. For those of you continuing, I offer this observation: "Sometimes I wish I'd been given the manual." Manuals, when well-written, provide valuable insights: what things are for, what they can do, how they operate, what happens if you press certain buttons, and what to do when things aren't working correctly. They even have the contact information of the all-knowing guru who can solve every problem. Unfortunately, I didn't receive a manual with me.

There's nothing wrong with PCs. If I were an avid gamer with time, I'd certainly own a PC for its vast selection of games. However, aside from a few unique titles, the extensive game selection at stores like CompUSA becomes repetitive. Initially, I feel envious, but soon realize it's just many variations of the same genres: first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. The numerous versions of Age of Empires, for example, become amusing: AoE with orcs, AoE with spaceships, AoE with fuzzy wombats! It's reminiscent of endless movie trailers that all start with the cliché: "In a world...

As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I quite dislike prequels because they technically go backward in the story rather than forward, which is an issue for every prequel. However, they do offer more story development. The combat feels sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents the completion of a side mission (the main story is not affected). Some gadgets are assigned to an inconvenient hotkey, requiring your hand to travel across the keyboard. It might seem minor, but during combat, it could potentially disrupt your combo.

Shadow Warrior (2013) has been significantly improved. The boss fights are amazing, and the weapons feel impressive—perhaps not quite at the level of Doom 2016’s, but still robust. Enemies aren't overly tough if you manage elemental and upgrade features wisely. The upgrade system is well-balanced and becomes less tedious once you understand it. Elemental features and limited ammo encourage you to use different weapons. There are many unique, interesting weapons—unlike the procedurally generated ones in Borderlands—that remain useful throughout most of the game. The music is fantastic, particularly the main theme and Stan Bush’s contributions.

So many things were done wrong. I'm not even sure where to start this review. This all pertains to MyCareer. My player is an outside scorer, PG, 1.71m tall, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Now, tell me, why does shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can't someone who is 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? In real life, I'm 1.87m. I made my first player with this height and noticed I can't reach a skill higher than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game inform me of this before I create a character or even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

In this installment of Assassin's Creed, the game truly excels in mechanics across all aspects, including ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, and more. I found myself more connected to the main character. Initially, the story begins roughly but improves significantly as the game progresses—something I've noticed with every AC game. Edward is a fascinating character, as are the side characters. The collectibles in this game felt meaningful, a sentiment I didn’t experience with previous entries. Perhaps it's because they seemed to have a more significant purpose in this game. While not required, they were fun to obtain, offering balanced rewards.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the funds to purchase gun parts. This leads to my main complaint: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook that, the game would be enjoyable. The hardsuit is fun to use, and HRV is an excellent concept. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction model is discouraging. If you don't mind this approach, then enjoy it. However, if you're like me and oppose pay-to-win schemes, let this one go; it's not our cup of tea.

Although not flawless, this game has been highly enjoyable. The save system and the possibility of sudden death can be frustrating. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around hour 10 out of approximately 20. I would have appreciated a save option to reload at that point. I've since used a third-party mod/save tool to prevent catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticle is small and the zoom is underpowered. Despite these issues, the game has been a blast. I'm not usually a zombie fan, but the blend of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up elements is fantastic. I play it as often as possible, always telling myself—just one more mission, one more supply run—or escaping to safety before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation, and ALB), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is impressive. Not sure exactly how many, but there’s a ton! The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the overall gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining, no kidding. However, if you're new to the strategy genre, it could take time to master. Don’t get discouraged; you will lose units. Just plan ahead, and always have anti-air and anti-tank.

I was initially skeptical about this game before I played it. I wasn't even sure about buying it. The whole portal gun and portal concept seemed odd to me, even though I enjoy science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. Simply amazing. It's not cheesy (well, occasionally), and each character has their own unique sense of humor and personality. The level design is superb. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to, if I can spare the time. I would never have considered it if I hadn't played the sequel.

Let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-), followed by my thoughts on this game. 

Pros: 
+ Some of the best characters 
+ Good story 
+ Loads of content 
+ Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you like) 
+ You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes fangirls, you can have a love interest) 

Cons: 
- Poor graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway) 
- Awkward love scenes 
- Invisible walls 
- One mission was boring, in my opinion, but everyone has different tastes 

Neutral: 
+- The protagonist you create can't talk; whether that's good or bad depends on personal preference. 

My thoughts: I love this game. This is probably one of the best RPGs or games in general I've ever played. If you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgic trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallett (at least in the UK) just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is perfect and very, very Generation One. Aside from that, it's a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often necessary and seamlessly integrated into combos, making it quite different from High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. There's a heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it briefly, and it felt quite ordinary. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There's a bug where, after an update to the terms of service appears and you click 'accept', the prompt just returns. You have to restart the client for it to function properly. While that's not too severe, why must I link my Steam and Gface accounts? They claim it's for DLC, but is that really necessary? It's irreversible, so now a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is average. It's clearly recognizable as a COD clone, but somehow, they've made the gunplay worse. How is that even possible?

4K resolution at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear—what's not to love? Check out the excellent port at this link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo. It's a great entry point if you're new to the series. Be aware there’s a lot of dialogue that can be skipped. Using a gamepad is recommended, though I had no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup, both fully rebindable. The price feels fair, and I wouldn't have regretted purchasing it. Over half the DLC is included for free, providing plenty to enjoy. Highly recommended for JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, as long as you don't mind breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches, it plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is a truly great and fun game, although the format can be somewhat annoying, where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story. I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play as Batman and another character. Using the controller for most parts of the game, and the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, especially when chasing the APC commanders, is quite enjoyable once you master skidding around corners.

This is an excellent FPS shooter—impressive in every way. It looks, sounds, and performs exceptionally well: engaging FPS mechanics, a compelling story, intriguing characters, flawless voice acting, and an outstanding soundtrack. It's not for the faint-hearted, though—some cutscenes are quite intense. When a game is this great overall, its flaws become more noticeable. Here's what stood out to me: - No SLI support, which was disappointing. I had to wait until I upgraded my card, as it struggled on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a decent single GPU card. - Annoyingly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language. I am Dutch, so please forgive any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability.

Graphics: The game is designed with a comic-like style. The graphics are very sleek with no unnecessary details and feature nice color schemes. It totally works for this game. The graphics can be set on 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card, 8GB memory, and it runs like clockwork (Windows 8.1).

Controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse or with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I've put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from CoD would be. But don’t buy this game thinking it's like CoD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I can't tell you how many times I hear new players complain about getting killed really fast. Oh, heaven forbid you get shot in the face and die. It's not like that doesn’t happen in real life or anything. Edit: I've been playing this game for a while now. I've invested a lot in it. One of the best multiplayer games around. A good choice when you’re not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm two hours in, and this game is hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, and the music is surprisingly high quality and fitting. The story and world have captured my interest, and the puzzles are enjoyable. The standout feature is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the genre began, you'll appreciate the jokes, parodies, and references. Even if you're new to RPGs, you'll find the humor entertaining. If you've played Final Fantasy VII or X, this game is a must-play. Without giving too much away, I had to stop after two hours to rest my cheeks from all the laughter and smiles. What a delight!

I'm really sorry. I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded appealing, but the execution didn't work for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this one completely unintuitive. Even after searching for guidance, I didn't find the gameplay fun. It also lacks a pause button, or if there is one, I couldn't find it. Considering that many sequences are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. Additionally, this game feels more like a series of cut scenes than gameplay, leaving me just sitting around, drumming my fingers.

This game... Phew, where to even start? It was absolutely beautiful. From the story to the graphics, I was hooked. The story wasn't just any story; it felt like I was the character, trying to figure out what came next. The gameplay was excellent, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (especially my fear of heights, which I discovered in the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or a sequel, I’d be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this; you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or "victory." Unlike previous games where you progressed through Earth's historical eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this game is set in the future, focused on colonizing a new planet. I appreciate that 2K took a fresh approach with new mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer. However, these additions can sometimes make the game feel overwhelming. One area for improvement could be incorporating new artwork, particularly in the environments encountered during interactions with other leaders.

Great game! Tons of replayability, and a very fun zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games. Edit: after 60+ hours of playing, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more "realistic" zombie games. It's designed as a survival horror—you must conserve ammo, heal your wounds, and take pills if you're infected. I find the zombies well animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends or chat with people through voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game. From the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have two major issues. No Australian servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, creating unbearable lag. Mind you, I played through the offline training mode, and it was stuttering or lagging as well. How does that even happen? Coupled with the poor ping, it just ruins the game. Everything artifacts like crazy - the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my overclocking. Set my GPU back to stock, and sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

Late last night, I finished this. The story itself may not be very deep or captivating, but the storytelling truly stands out. The atmosphere is rich, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, though I was somewhat disappointed by the limited number of bosses in the game. However, future games provide an opportunity to address this. The combat offers a suitable challenge, albeit leaning towards the easier side. Leveling up Batman was not particularly satisfying. The gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign introduce enjoyable new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas adds a pleasing sense of progression.

To the Moon" is not just a game; it is a profound experience and one of the best of my life. Think Telltale's "The Walking Dead" is sad? It doesn't hold a candle to "To the Moon"! Never have I been so profoundly moved by something fictional. This masterpiece epitomizes storytelling, and the soundtrack is a beautifully charming accompaniment. Yes, the controls can be a bit tricky, and gameplay isn't its strong suit, but the story is so exceptional that I didn't mind. Additionally, the humor is delightful and doesn't detract from the story's distinguished nature. Plus, the "Doctor Who" references are endless.

Bastion is an outstanding game with an engaging storyline. Set in the aftermath of a calamity, you begin rebuilding on the bastion. The game offers numerous choices, including what structures to build for advantages, which weapons to use, and which power-ups and drinks provide bonus effects. The art style and music are superb, with vibrant visuals that defy the notion that the apocalypse must be dull. Most impressively, the game features narration that responds to your actions. For example, if you pick up a weapon and later swap it for another in the armory, the narration remarks on your choice of the new weapon.

I originally bought this game during its early development, back when the only currency was spacebux and there wasn't a "tech tree." At this stage, the game was great. All the guns were equally overpowerful, creating no imbalance; anyone could defeat anyone at any time. Back then, the game offered unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would expect that a game boasting "bajillions of guns" would provide more than six weapon slots and three loadouts without additional cost. At one time, I had about three pages' worth of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for more because, personally, that's where I found it entertaining.

This game was a surprising gem. Often, rave reviews can be misleading, but in this case, they genuinely reflect the enjoyment of this neat little game. It's an unusual blend of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. Despite my initial hesitations, I decided to try a melee tank. I was pleasantly surprised with the result and ended up trying more characters as they were unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface are charming. Now, I use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, and I love this game. When I put on my headphones, I lose myself in the gameplay for hours. It's been a while since a game has captivated me like this. The music sets the perfect mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate each combat encounter, and they've optimized combat very well. I had doubts about the naval combat system, but it’s so exciting to defeat multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose is to fail to retreat. If combat looks overwhelming, just retreat, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks to the developers for an amazing experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced many changes, particularly for the series’ protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original may be upset by the changes to their beloved character, it’s arguably for the better, as this new game by Ninja Theory demonstrates. DMC serves as the perfect entry point for newcomers. It explores the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and chronicles his transformation from cynicism to selflessness. The game weaves a clear narrative arc for this new Dante, making him a compelling character to follow. The story follows Dante as he is introduced to the corrupt world he once willfully ignored.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, filled with detail, happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It balances seriousness with humor seamlessly. The character design is outstanding, featuring a variety of personalities and hidden depths. This game stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, an uncommon concept in the genre. Drawing inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've experienced, it’s evident this game is exceptional. Additionally, it boasts the best soundtrack I've heard in a long time.

I am recommending this solely because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor. I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to evoke a reaction from me. The other half of the game attempts to portray a person in mental decline, dealing with obsession, hallucination, and depression. In theory, it's a cool idea, but the game took me 10 minutes to complete, even with reading and absorbing every detail.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that presents you with a concept and then lets you explore it. It’s an excellent way to challenge your mind while still having fun. While the game isn't heavily focused on story, it did pave the way for one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play and complete it when I'm bored, and I love revisiting the game to see what laid the foundation for a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple to explain. You use portals to your advantage, combined with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons: one you press and one that requires a cube.

If you're able to overlook the bugs (I personally encountered two: one minor and the other quite annoying—edit: both bugs are resolved), and are seeking a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most reviews discuss specifications, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~€200), Radeon RX480 (~€200), Z170 Pro - Gaming (~€150), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~€70). ~€650 is certainly within the medium price range, though this rig is quite new. It achieves almost constant 60+ fps on high settings with V-Sync enabled. I find it hard to believe that 90% of the comments claim to have an overkill setup and get only 20 fps.

Remember Age of Mythology? It's been quite a while since we've seen an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes remarkably close to my personal favorite RTS. It combines a grand strategy mode reminiscent of Risk, hitting the spot perfectly. I try not to be overly biased, even though this game allows you to transform into a dragon, supporting your troops by attacking and commanding unit production and direction simultaneously. Honestly, I appreciate complex RTS games today. Think of Civilization V, for instance. However, such games often cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resources into a single, complicated mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is beautiful; together, they create truly impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, while cleverly subverting RPG tropes. And all of this is without even mentioning the world, characters, story, and gameplay—I could write entire pages about it. Instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your final breath, play this game.

I've only had this game for a few months, but in that time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, as evident in various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still trying to master; however, this extensive strategy provides numerous ways to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. The game, in my opinion, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself completely engaged in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is progressing.

Warframe is enjoyable for the first few hours. Afterward, you'll notice that what remains is repetitive combat, enemies, and gameplay. However, the developers actively update the game with substantial content changes, new warframes, and other features. It's a good game for casual play, though it might only capture your interest for a few months unless you particularly enjoy grinding. The significant advantage is that the game is free, so I recommend giving it a try. If you're seeking a quick gaming fix, it's worth exploring.

This game is very boring. I purchased it thinking it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy,' a popular PS2 game. Sadly, it falls short. You go around absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger, but the gameplay lacks smoothness, and the levels aren't inventive. Instead, it presents a surreal horror show—not the entertaining kind, but one that leaves you feeling depressed, questioning if life is what it ought to be. Every creature, from pets to humans, makes me wonder if the creators had an interest in taxidermy.

Certainly, let me provide a polished version with the required changes:

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was eager to try this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh, wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" Unfortunately, it wasn't. The game starts by asking you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat. There's no option for independent or third party. A bit disappointed but still optimistic, I continued to explore what I could do. I must give the game credit; the character customization, although limited, is quite enjoyable to experiment with. It's amusing that it's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign.

The story of Fallout 3 was superior. Settlements interfere with the narrative to the point where you'll end up resenting managing them instead of engaging with the story. Some keys are hardcoded and can't be reassigned. The game is riddled with bugs. At one point, my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, and I had to research console commands to retrieve it. Power armor is essentially handed to you at the start, with power cores readily available in trader shops. This significantly devalues power armor compared to previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, as is the game overall, but it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. It is far more stable in comparison. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. This title was overhyped given how disappointing it truly is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hours to reach the end - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 What I liked: - Visuals up until the last level (ice caves) - The story isn't great, but the ending (after the credits) slightly redeemed my time spent on this game What I disliked: - The visuals in the last level were uninteresting - Gameplay in the last level became significantly harder, making it frustrating to repeat tasks until getting them right - Achievements are excessively difficult. Only less than 2.1% of players have achieved 13 out of 15 achievements!

Pros: + great graphics    
Cons: - bugs (especially environmental issues, such as getting stuck or your shots hitting an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy)  
- the game feels like it is handholding or babysitting you  
- poor AI  
- enemies always seem to know your location once spotted  
- the enemy's accuracy is frustratingly high, similar to the first Ghost Warrior  
- terrible checkpoints and save options  
- uninteresting story that was hard to engage with  
I wouldn't recommend this game unless it's heavily discounted, even then, I find playing it a tedious chore. Finishing it just feels like a task to move on to the next game in my library. Given my experience with the first Ghost Warrior, I likely won't finish this one.

Review from 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game; servers are offline, and you can't play. No compres este juego; los servidores están offline. No puedes jugar. While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: "Go on, take the money and run." I spent 73 minutes playing the game. Just an hour in, and it's awesome! Some guns are overpowered, and matchmaking is sometimes unfair, but hey, in BF3, matchmaking is worse. New players matched with higher-level players weren't realistic; you could shoot them in the face, and nothing happened!

I can understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. I have a Vive and am more interested in room-sized games using the controllers. The game's universe is initially awe-inspiring in its scale, but that scale also hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to do anything interesting at the outset were both too steep for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, I would find it compelling. However, I lack both, and there are many other VR games I'd prefer to spend my time on.

Hands down, this is my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun players need not apply. The recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons nearly always result in death unless they graze you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are necessary to stay on target. There is no magical ammunition pool; if you reload halfway through your magazine frequently, you'll end up with a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run indefinitely; sprinting too long affects your aim as you gasp heavily until you catch your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Standing accuracy suffers.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out; I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people reported. I loved that game; it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you succeeded. As for XCOM 2, I love it. The game plays well for me on medium settings, and I am using a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game was set to high, and it ran a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. When I lowered it to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm simply lucky regarding game issues, but most negative reviews seem to come from some very entitled individuals.

+ RPG leveling  
+ Wide variety of ship types  
+ Physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles  
+ Easy-to-learn resource management  
+ Dark humor  

- Grind intensive (if underutilizing civilian station types)  
- Subpar AI teammates  
- Low variety of equipment types  
- Low variety of leveling skills (no branching)  

Listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses, there's still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and really picks up. Even with a low variety of equipment, it feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to extend the game's life is through mods. Fight for Universe is easily the standout, but Big Fight for Beef is also very good.

World leaders gather amid uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive at the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future following this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among more than 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be minimal. Anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to coincide with the WEF's event in Davos.

Deadline Approaches for Fiat-GM Deal

Fiat and General Motors (GM) must reach an agreement by midnight on 1 February to resolve their disagreement over a potential takeover. At this deadline, Fiat gains the right to sell its car division to GM, as outlined in the alliance formed in 2000. GM, which is facing losses in its European operations, no longer wishes to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday due to hopes of a resolution. It is believed the U.S. firm is offering approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to end the agreement. GM contends the deal was nullified by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising initiative. The 2000 deal was part of a competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal criticizes Iraq war cost, stating billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has said. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales expressed these views on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas Midnight Mass. The cardinal used his Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have spoken out against the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticized the fact that "billions" have been spent on war instead of being used to alleviate "dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

British stars were denied major Oscars as UK talents failed to win in the acting and directing categories. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not receive the director or screenplay awards, and no prize was awarded to star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress award to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo did not win Best Supporting Actor awards. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film Award for her gritty drama "Wasp." Arnold, who presented children's television shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. "Wasp" tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, winning over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, a renowned writer and producer best known for her work on the 70s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide—a record for an independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, she began her career as a production assistant, rising through the ranks to become an assistant director before collaborating with Carpenter. Hill was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 70s that were typically held by men.

Broadband is fueling online expression, with fast web access encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. They state that having an always-on, fast connection is changing how people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is rapidly increasing. The Demos report examined broadband's impact on people's internet habits. It found that more than half logged on before breakfast. One in five even admitted to waking up in the middle of the night to browse. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos is returning to U.S. courts as the Russian oil and gas company continues its fight for survival. The firm is undergoing a breakup by Russian authorities to pay a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., aiming to use international business law to stop the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to state oil firm Rosneft, despite disruptions during the state auction. Yukos lawyers argue that the auction violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders are determined to pursue any buyer of its assets through all available legal means.

Voters are flocking to the Blog Awards site as voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the year's best web blogs—online spaces where people publish their thoughts. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official site experienced such heavy traffic that it had to temporarily close due to the influx of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a significant year, especially with a top U.S. dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs, noting that more than 12,000 are added daily. According to U.S. research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, a blog is created every 5.8 seconds. However, less than 40% are updated at least once every two months.

The Chinese state press has reported that the China Three Gorges Project Corp is defying a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams. Despite directives, the builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the Xiluodu Dam, as revealed by the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 significant construction projects suspended due to inadequate environmental checks. According to the Beijing News, the company might opt to pay a fine instead. Additionally, the firm has ignored orders to cease construction at two other sites—the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 projects identified by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for lacking mandated environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points with a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne accidentally volleyed over David James' head into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United looked unlikely to secure the win they needed to challenge Chelsea for the title. Their approach was more labored than patient, and they crafted just one chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

The new health minister for Wales, Dr. Brian Gibbons, acknowledges there are important lessons to learn from England in addressing waiting lists. On his first full day in office, following the departure of Jane Hutt, Dr. Gibbons admitted there are "big challenges" but emphasized that the "essentials" are in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats asserted that Dr. Gibbons needs to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists composed "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, formerly a GP in Blaengwynfi in the upper Afan Valley, and now AM for Aberavon, mentioned that NHS staff desire a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." Ms. Hutt faced significant challenges with the length of waiting lists during her tenure.

Ferguson Hails Man Utd's Resolve  

Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and weren't going to lose."  

He reflected on the fixture, noting, "We've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do."  

Ferguson also commended senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought composure to the midfield, which no other player has.

A documentary that offers a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Titled "A Different Story," it will be screened in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from February 10-20. The film features Michael discussing his career and personal life, from his Wham! days to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be present. The 93-minute film includes Michael's reflections on his early Wham! days, his later career, legal battles with record label Sony, and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

Digital music downloads are now being included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart incorporates data from sales of music downloads, which were previously confined to a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two in Billboard's pop chart and tops the digital chart. Download sales will also be included in the UK singles chart later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. Now, they will be combined with physical singles sales and airplay data to form the new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws have hit a major spammer hard, as the internet's self-proclaimed "spam king" seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the individual behind OptinRealBig.com and billions of spam messages, stated that lawsuits have driven the company to file for Chapter 11. OptinRealBig was embroiled in several legal disputes, most prominently with Microsoft, which is seeking millions in damages. The company believes that Chapter 11 will aid in resolving its legal issues while allowing it to continue operations. Ranked as the third-largest spammer globally by the junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptinRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending emails that breached anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, alleging that Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies a rift with Santini. Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has refuted claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to personality clashes at White Hart Lane. There was newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems. He spoke to me recently and said this matter is absolutely personal." Arnesen stated he could not shed light on the issues that led Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added, "Jacques has never gone into detail about what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave Scotland an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put Ireland in command by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who scored 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side looks forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will aim for their coach Matt Williams's first Six Nations victory against Italy in Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Britain's economic future will be central to Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced. Speaking after Cabinet members held their final meeting at No. 10 before the anticipated election announcement, he expressed confidence that voters would appreciate Labour's track record of stability and growth, and their commitment to maintaining this trend. Meanwhile, the Tories have detailed their strategies to address "yob culture," and the Liberal Democrats have shared more about their plans to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury urged all three parties not to exploit public fears during the election. In an open letter, he implored them not to turn the election into a contest over who can most effectively alarm voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to run AAAs in Sheffield Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAAs championships. U.S.-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy hopes to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in excellent form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed in midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with Cragg occupying top spot.

Robinson aims for dual-code success: England rugby union captain Jason Robinson targets dual triumph over Australia on Saturday. A former rugby league international who switched codes in 2000, Robinson leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later, at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the Tri-Nations final. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England seeks their third consecutive autumn international victory after wins over Canada and South Africa, while also avenging June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain hopes to end 34 years of failure against Australia with a win at Elland Road.

Internet users are being warned to avoid a scam website that falsely claims to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate because it uses an older version of the Disaster Emergency Committee's official webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with this fraudulent site and has reported it to the police. This website is the latest in a series of scams exploiting the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is included in a spam email currently circulating. The email's subject line, "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," and its content are marked by poor grammar and spelling typical of many phishing attempts.

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses as part of its plan to significantly enhance nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications has called for bids from local, Arab, and foreign companies. The selected company will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The Ministry aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years" and to create a "highly visible and dynamic telecommunication sector."
