Bidding details will be available on the Ministry's website on February 9, with a roadshow planned for investors in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to internet security as older individuals, particularly women, increasingly take charge of protecting home computers from malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to shield PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks increased by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for the internet security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are reaching a diverse group of internet users. Approximately 40% of those buying home internet security programs are retired, with an average increase of 13.2% over the past three years. Notably, more retired women (53%) are purchasing security software compared to retired men. The research reflects evolving stereotypes and demographics of web users, along with heightened awareness of the risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, providing ample space to fill. Increasingly, iPod owners fill that space with audio content from a diverse group of producers. This phenomenon is called "podcasting," strongly advocated by former MTV host and VJ, Adam Curry. Despite its name, derived from the Apple iPod, you don't need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show that podcasters often create from home. All they require is a microphone, a PC, and editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen for free.

Andrea Levy, winner of the Orange Prize, has seen her book "Small Island" win the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award. She is now favored to win the overall prize, having triumphed over Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." Geraldine McCaughrean has secured the Children's Fiction Award for the third time for "Not the End of the World." All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which awards a £25,000 prize. A panel including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will finalize the overall winner on 25 January, with the announcement later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill lists Levy's novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos will return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has bought its main asset. Yukos intends to sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' U.S. lawyers will attempt to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government ignored a U.S. court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for purchasing the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal, which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion on Sunday at a state-provoked auction, has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured their Scottish Cup quarter-final win against Livingston with two early goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring within 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister then scored the second, meeting Saul Mikoliunas’ cross at the back post, effectively putting the game beyond Livingston. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held firm. The opening goal resulted from Gus Bahoken's foul on Miller 35 yards out. McAllister floated the free kick into the box, and Miller outjumped the stationary defense, looping his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With only 10 minutes passed, Mikoliunas raced down the right, delivering a cross where McAllister headed past the goalkeeper.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service that enables customers to rent substantial computing power by the hour. This Sun Grid offering charges users $1 (53p) for an hour's processing and storage on systems managed by Sun. Grid computing has become a buzzword in a company that believes computing capacity is as critical a commodity as hardware and software. Sun compares grid computing to the evolution of electricity, suggesting that it could develop similarly to utilities like electricity and water, according to Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for just a buck an hour?" he commented during a webcast at Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Scotland's Justice Minister has issued a warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating her intention to "hit them where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson highlighted that exclusion orders are among several measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts to address the issue. However, the minister emphasized that curbing sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches is a primary goal. Ms. Jamieson spoke ahead of the Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism historically linked to some supporters of both clubs has become a significant focus for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives to discuss the matter.

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film Beyond the Sea in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack as Darin. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended with her British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds vs. Saracens (Fri) Headingley, Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT: The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the fixed line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobile phones. It found that people keep their fixed line phones because call charges are lower, yet most respondents indicated that the future is definitely mobile. Nokia-sponsored research indicated that mobiles and fixed lines are used for different purposes. Home phones are often used for longer calls, while mobile conversations tend to be shorter, usually between mobiles and with friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents said they opted for their fixed phone because it remains cheaper to use than a mobile.

MPs Promote Lords Replacement Plan

A group of MPs has sought to increase pressure on Tony Blair regarding reform of the House of Lords by unveiling a detailed plan for change. This cross-party group has introduced a draft bill that suggests a smaller second chamber with 70% of its members elected. Since 1999, MPs and peers have struggled to reach an agreement on reform, particularly after 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group believes it can garner support to remove the last 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers, citing opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms, and there have been indications that Labour's manifesto will propose changes, at least to the powers of the Lords.

Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equaled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64 seconds but ran 0.04 seconds slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final.

A U.S. woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are programmed to expire on a specific date. The woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer it needs refilling even when it does not. The lawsuit aims to represent all U.S. customers who purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world’s largest printer manufacturer, declined to comment on the legal matter. HP ink cartridges are equipped with chip technology to detect low ink levels and alert the user to replace them. However, the lawsuit asserts that the chips also deactivate the cartridges on a set date, irrespective of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio, a UK broadcaster, will become the first station globally to offer radio via 3G mobile networks. In partnership with the technology firm Sydus, the station will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from the Virgin website to enable the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, stated: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will pioneer this offering, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland added: "This application will enable anyone, anywhere, to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music on Isle of Wight Bill

Roxy Music will perform at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as the headliner for the three-day event, which takes place from June 10–12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on Saturday night. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other hits including "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy.

Captains lining up for an aid match include Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, one of four Six Nations captains in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also part of the northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," Woodward said. It will be a chance for Woodward to evaluate some of his options before announcing his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he added.

Prince crowned 'top music earner.' Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists like Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer made $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, album, and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place as she earned $54.9 million (£29.5 million) while on her global Re-Invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, with their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9 million (£13.4 million) last year. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. His 2004 tour earned $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of Musicology.

Walmart and Eli Lilly, two prominent American companies, have launched advertising campaigns to address criticisms about their products and corporate practices. As the world's largest retailer, Walmart ran over 100 full-page ads in national newspapers to counter critiques regarding its pay, benefits, and promotion strategies. Simultaneously, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly announced a campaign to refute "false" claims about its product, Prozac. Walmart began its efforts with ads in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from company president Lee Scott, who insisted it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." "There are many 'urban legends' about Walmart, but the facts remain.

The Tories are outlining plans for policing whereby local communities would go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner. These plans were unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard stated that this new role would replace the "inconspicuous" police authorities. Howard clarified that this office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats argued that the plan could allow extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour criticized the Tories' "extravagant" promises regarding policing. Responding to the plans, Jan Berry, chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, emphasized the importance of maintaining operational independence. She stated, "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches." Berry warned that these plans could lead to those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground.

The UK Opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here’s a guide to the plan: individuals coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU, who plan to stay for six months or more and are from countries with high rates of TB, would need to have a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who wish to stay for a year or more will have to undergo a full medical examination. Tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV are the main concerns. A positive test for TB would automatically result in visa applications being denied. All other conditions would be addressed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris Promise Raises Welsh Hopes Has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These questions are occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of the three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in." A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half.

Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart at number one with their latest release, Some Cities, replacing the flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters. The album follows their single "Black and White Town," which peaked at number six. R&B star Nelly claims the new number one single with "Over and Over," a collaboration with Tim McGraw. New singles from Girls Aloud, Akon, Kaiser Chiefs, Futureheads, and Usher also populate the top ten. The latest re-release from Elvis Presley, "(Marie's The Name) His Latest Flame," entered at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." Hip-hop artist Akon's "Locked Up" stands at number five, while promising Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs achieve their second chart hit with "Oh My God" at number six.

Davies favors Gloucester future. Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with the English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to stay where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is on a year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold, forcing him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the Wales management's request, he admitted before moving to Gloucester that he was upset with the way he was treated.

Cabinet ministers are reportedly displeased with plans to redirect Whitehall funds to mitigate council tax bills, as acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown reassigned £512 million from central to local government budgets. Mr. Raynsford mentioned having some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers regarding these plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must provide quality services without significant increases in council tax. This central government cash is part of a £1 billion package aimed at helping local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, coinciding with a general election year. Mr. Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in well-run local authorities.

The Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, featuring four African players including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, is gearing up to compete in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab team to participate in a European competition, will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, was instrumental in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. He recently moved to Israel after a short tenure with South Africa's Hellenic club. Having won the Israeli Cup last season, the club is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa, and strongly promotes peace and cooperation within Israel.

A report suggests that lowering drink-drive limits by a third could save more lives than previously estimated. Research from University College London suggests reducing the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood could save 65 lives annually. These findings are published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill proposes changes to speeding fines, but not to the drink-drive limit. Conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, the research also predicts 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads, compared to 2003. He estimates this change could save the country £119 million a year. A 1998 Department of Transport document previously estimated such a measure could save 50 lives annually.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle within the depletion region, while the array design offers a substantial detection area of 512×512 μm². Rather than detecting the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures pulse width—the time required for the voltage to revert to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-intensive and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is developed using the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, consuming an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system’s functionality is successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) can reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming AVs would readily allow external control by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings. Meanwhile, user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) face a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization: dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level involves a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model, considering both AVs and HVs in the fleet.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This advancement not only brings larger and more tangible objects into a quantum behavior regime but also spurs ideas for using mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, and as precision force sensors that surpass the standard quantum limit. However, the essentially linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a wider class of quantum motion states, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested overcoming this limit by achieving strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While there have been experimental demonstrations of such quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have yet to access nonclassical motion states.

Online reviews help customers evaluate products and make purchasing decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated by fake reviews, often created by professional spammers who continually develop sophisticated strategies to bypass detection. These strategies are challenging to capture because they evolve quickly, vary across different spammers and products, and often remain unknown. Additionally, most existing detection tools prioritize accuracy, which does not necessarily align with maintaining the credibility of product reviews. To tackle these challenges, we propose a minimax game in which spammers and detectors compete based on their practical goals, beyond just detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game result in stable detectors that are resilient to a range of mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system configured as a lambda. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, with solutions following a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control the fidelity of the transfer, the excited state's population, and robustness simultaneously. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above \(10^{-4}\). The robustness of our shaped pulses surpasses that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we explore the negative log-likelihood function landscape of Gaussian mixture models with any number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there are multiple local minima that aren't globally optimal, even for well-separated mixtures. We demonstrate that all local minima share a structure that partially identifies the true mixture's component centers. Each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting several Gaussians to one true component and fitting one Gaussian to several true components. Our findings are applicable when the true mixture components meet a specific separation condition, remaining valid even with over-or under-specified component numbers. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we achieve sharper results concerning the scaling with component separation.

We examine the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, defined by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, the Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ within it by the dual group $g^t$. In the second, the Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is formed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

This work presents a generalized study of human gait based on existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. The hybrid model combines metabolic energy minimization strategies with a non-linear description of mass center libration to simulate the walk-run transition. Experimental data across various speed regimes suggest that the trajectory perimeter of the mass center is crucial for quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and labs at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method is based on time regularization, allowing us to maintain the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size whenever two planets approach closely. We use a high-order MVS scheme, enabling integration with large time steps when far from close encounters. This algorithm can resolve near-collisions (with mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problems like the solar system. We demonstrate the long-term behavior on systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as Mercury and show that for an equivalent cost, it achieves much better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is an entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension relative to the system size, it is very challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. As a comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinctive multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We develop a method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a range of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can disrupt the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, resulting in a more complex multipolar structure, offering a pathway to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. We provide numerical evidence indicating that all multipole moments tend to be larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only mild constraints on fuzzballs. However, future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the LISA mission will significantly enhance these bounds.

Reasoning about graphs that evolve over time is a challenging concept in various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. A common scenario involves edges that represent either short-term interactions, like messaging, or long-term structural connections, such as friendship. In practice, long-term edges are often determined by humans, which can be costly and suboptimal for downstream tasks. To address these challenges, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders. Our model learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing their communication. By enabling temporal attention to drive between-node feature propagation, our approach provides greater flexibility and circumvents the limitations associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between them. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW, for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. Since our PCW is designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating possible adverse effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs. The long-term goal is to achieve strong atom-mediated links between phonons of vibration and photons propagating in the GMs of the PCW, enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between these groups of adjacent dimensions are split epimorphisms. The interest in such splittings arises from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum form a global Mackey functor. Therefore, the splittings suggest that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra, $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings indicate the regularity of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects suppress the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression introduce significant uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys like Euclid or LSST. In this first paper of a two-part series, we utilize simulations to create a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its corresponding covariance matrix. These datasets are corrected for baryonic effects using the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to rapidly predict the baryonic power suppression, enabling us to conduct a likelihood inference analysis within a standard $\Lambda$CDM cosmology framework that includes both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, pose significant challenges for audio processing. However, developing speech processing models that manage such diverse conditions is crucial for language acquisition studies. Researchers focus on the quantity and quality of speech children hear and produce, and this is helpful for early diagnosis and assessing remediation effects. In this paper, we introduce our approach to designing an open-source neural network capable of classifying audio segments into categories: vocalizations from the child wearing the recording device, those from other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. We compiled diverse child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings in 10 languages.

Density-based clustering hinges on linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. By referencing a true, albeit unknown, population structure, we can frame the clustering problem within a standard inferential setting. Here, the ideal population clustering is defined by the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation, known as modal clustering, associates groups with the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is necessary, and selecting the appropriate amount of smoothing—which governs the shape of the density and possibly the modal structure—is crucial for identifying the final partition. This work addresses the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to interference between standard model and higher-dimension operators, which parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes obstruct the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading contribution to cancel in the total diboson rate correction. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recapturing sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable generated only by these non-interfering operators, relegating their effects to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a primary objective of many analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often been skeptical of analyses with a causal focus. The advent of "data science" offers an opportunity to redefine data analysis to naturally include causal inference from observational data. Like others, we categorize the contributions of data science into three tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction, which encompasses causal inference. An explicit classification of these tasks is crucial to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics needed for each task. We argue that failing to adequately describe the role of expert knowledge in data analysis leads to widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) requires the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. Conventionally, these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is not explicitly clear what issues arise if this doesn't occur. This note indicates that, within a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems concerning entanglement entropy. Resolving this contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which aligns with the typical statement at weak coupling. The argument is broad and does not depend on supersymmetry or a specific UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can result in unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been elusive. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and identify a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for exploring the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are mathematical models used across various fields such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering due to their intuitive modeling appeal. Despite their extensive use, the lack of analytic solutions often complicates estimating ODE parameters from data, especially in models with numerous variables and parameters. This paper introduces a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that remains efficient and accurate even for complex models. The proposed method approximates an ODE model using a state-space model founded on numerical solver equations. This approach enables rapid estimation by circumventing the need to compute an entire numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior distribution is obtained through a variational Bayes method, specifically the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.).

We explore the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry-broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) neighboring an s-wave superconductor. The differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes are significantly influenced by the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the impact of a chiral chemical potential, namely, the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the junction's transport characteristics. Notably, a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs emerges via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions, where the spin polarization is opposite in each region and highly sensitive to chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has proven to be an effective and controllable technique for adjusting the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, and this method has been utilized in various applications. Crucially, it provides a way to grade the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. A concern with this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is prone to oxidation. We report our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. Results indicate that after an initial drop of up to 40% within a few weeks post-implantation, the conductivity decreases very slowly, by about 10%, over the following year.

We present a new Skyrme-like conserved current within the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, based on the concept of hidden local symmetry. The related charge corresponds to the Skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Furthermore, there are singular configurations that can be viewed as \( n_f=1 \) baryons charged under this new symmetry. In this framework, vector mesons act as the Chern-Simons vector fields on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the \( n_f=1 \) baryon. We propose that this current accurately represents the effective baryon current at low energies. This approach offers a unified perspective on two types of baryons, enabling a natural transformation between them. Moreover, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be seen as akin to a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents an intriguing opportunity to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically examine how the interplay of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially devised to quantify standard (tunneling) Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components. We demonstrate that their amplitudes can be widely adjusted through the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. of Turbul. 2020), which highlight that dipoles are as crucial to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it has been found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small, fast-moving cores and another family of larger, slowly moving ones, which can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both families differ significantly, with only the former being self-similar. The latter accounts for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, as its vortices form the dipoles and streams. Mechanisms for the growth of this slow component are discussed.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an invaluable framework for designing various quantum algorithms. Typically, the running time of these quantum algorithms is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the duration required by the quantum walk to locate a vertex of interest with high probability. This article presents enhanced upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to multiple CTQW-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we apply our methods to the glued-trees problem, improving the hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Moreover, our approaches significantly improve the precision dependence of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to identify a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, as demonstrated by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry, or "loss-cone," EMRIs, previously considered the main sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in nuclear star clusters and gravitational capture. Here, we highlight an alternative formation channel: wet EMRI formation assisted by accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially on inclined orbits and drives them to migrate towards the MBH. This process significantly boosts the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have little information about them—no interaction history with items, no user profile, and no social connections with other users. Despite this, we aim for our recommender systems to captivate users at first sight, encouraging them to remain on the website and become active participants. This challenge, known as the new user cold-start problem, is vital for a company's growth and even its survival. Existing solutions for user cold-start recommendations either demand additional user involvement, such as an interview process, or rely on supplementary information like user demographics, locations, or social relationships. However, users may be reluctant to participate in interviews, and such side information is often unavailable for cold-start users.

Deep learning has resolved numerous issues beyond the capabilities of heuristic algorithms. It has been successfully applied in wireless communications, despite current radio systems being well-understood with optimal algorithms for many tasks. Although gains have been achieved by learning individual receiver components, a better strategy involves jointly learning the entire receiver. This often leads to a challenging nonlinear problem, making the optimal solution difficult to implement. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, Deeprx, which executes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. We ensure accurate channel estimation by carefully constructing the convolutional neural network's input, utilizing both data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically employs a set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs by mutation. Often, a corpus includes thousands of similar inputs, resulting in a lack of diversity that can lead to inefficient fuzzing efforts due to exhaustive mutations from all available seeds. To tackle this, fuzzers offer distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the complete corpus. Common practice indicates that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds enhances fuzzing efficiency, which we systematically explore. We present the results from over 34 cpu-years of fuzzing using five distillation approaches to understand their impact on discovering bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into distinct groups, each of which possesses similar (isomorphic) state transition structures. As such, they can be relabeled into a common template. Based on this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain independent of the number of agents, even under partial observation. This scalable supervisor does not require recomputation, regardless of changes in the number of agents within the system. We extend our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations are a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced using temporal windowing, based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. The method uses a Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix due to the Toeplitz structure. Notably, it employs a temporal window, not necessarily rectangular, before spectral estimation, marking a first in ENF. Krylov matrices enable fast matrix inversions. This method surpasses state-of-the-art ENF estimation techniques, especially with a short time window of 1 second in power recordings. In speech recordings, it delivers highly accurate results in terms of time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to integrate advanced statistical dimension reduction techniques into Python as a unified package. It features three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust m-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, it offers regularized regression estimators utilizing these reduced dimensions, from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust m-regression. The package includes both classical and robust pre-processing tools, such as generalized spatial signs, along with specialized plotting and cross-validation features. Consistent with the scikit-learn API, direpack's estimators can seamlessly integrate into learning pipelines, whether statistical or machine learning, within that framework.

Nonlinear fluorescence emission is widely used for high spatial resolution optical imaging. We examined the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond, where fluorescence reduction occurs with high-power laser excitation. This increases fluorescence emission nonlinearity and alters the spatial frequency distribution of the image. Employing a differential excitation protocol, we extracted high spatial frequency information. By modulating the laser power, the spatial resolution improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Owing to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we anticipate this method can enhance spatial resolution in sensing and biological labeling using defects in solids.

When random effects correlate with sample design variables, using individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) in forming a pseudo-likelihood fails to deliver asymptotically unbiased inference. To address this, we develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution to achieve unbiased inference when generating hyperparameters of the random effects. Our approach contrasts with frequentist methods that depend on numerical integration, showing that only the Bayesian method offers unbiased estimation regarding the sampling design distribution and consistency with the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example, based on a survey of business establishments, highlight the effectiveness of our method across diverse modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work concludes recent developmental efforts that integrate traditional survey estimation strategies with the Bayesian modeling approach, providing a bridge between these two rich, yet distinct, sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene—feature more complex atomic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. These materials’ reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, alongside novel properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, significant nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. They may also exhibit unique electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic characteristics, and structural phase transformations. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was curated to showcase recent experimental and theoretical advancements in these materials.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was discovered that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described as a combination of several exponential processes, two of which are crucial. These primary processes succeed each other over a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also allowed differentiation of two orientational relaxation processes: the first is due to the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is related to the motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated substantial retrieval accuracy and efficiency for large-scale image retrieval. The optimization of discrete hash bits remains a core focus in these methods. Typically, an activation function like $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$ is used, with a quantization loss minimized to approximate discrete values. However, this approach can lead to hash bits becoming trapped in the saturated regions of the activation functions, a phenomenon we term the "dead bits problem (DBP)." Furthermore, traditional quantization loss can exacerbate DBP. In response, we introduce a straightforward yet effective gradient amplifier that operates prior to the activation functions to mitigate DBP.

We study the phenomenology of an SU(2) triplet scalar with zero hypercharge, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We explore scenarios where the triplets are stable, contributing to dark matter density, or where they decay via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The stable case faces constraints from disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and dark matter direct detection experiments, while the decaying triplets are limited by existing multilepton collider searches. A two-step electroweak phase transition with a stable triplet and negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection, while an unstable triplet with a mass under $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than anticipated in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (often called "pericenter glow"). This scenario proposes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, which gains eccentricity $e_f$ after the gas disc disperses due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, forming a belt of width $2ae_f$. However, narrower belts might occur if the planetesimals start with eccentricity, possibly due to earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, primordial eccentricity might result from instabilities that increase disc eccentricity without planet involvement.

Typically, an electron is considered to have one kind of kinetic energy, but could it possess more due to its spin, charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is effectively described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model. However, experimental observations beyond this linear regime are limited. We present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated-wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique. We identify two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, along with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that intensify as the wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by altering the extent of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the Gaia mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events the Milky Way has experienced. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by Gaia for almost all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages available, after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is crucial for most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article presents "intrinsic," an R package that features advanced, likelihood-based estimators for determining a dataset's intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To make these estimators easily accessible, the package provides intuitive, high-level functions supported by efficient low-level routines. Intrinsic offers models within two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category includes the two-nn and gride models, which perform inference using both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The second category features hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising advancements in spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems, one utilizing a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and the other comprising 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), were proposed and modeled for image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results regarding the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNOs under current pulse stimulation, the recognition task for handwritten digits demonstrates that an RC system using a single MSM excels in image classification. Furthermore, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can be effectively addressed by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs, as confirmed through second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are essential in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we uncover a surprising result of popularity-based rankings: the fewer items that report a given signal, the higher the share of overall traffic they collectively attract. This "few-get-richer" effect occurs in contexts with few distinct item classes (e.g., left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources) and where items are ranked by popularity. We analytically show that this effect arises when people predominantly click on top-ranked items and exhibit diverse preferences for item classes. Through simulations, we assess how the effect’s strength varies with different assumptions about the environment and human behavior. We further test our predictions in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings hold significant implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Weight pruning is widely acknowledged as an effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (DNN), thus achieving acceleration across various platforms. However, many pruning techniques involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, often leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, called pattern-based sparsity, which includes pattern and connectivity sparsity, achieving both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. With meticulously designed patterns, our proposed pruning consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across different DNN structures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework also includes pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pruning, and weight training simultaneously. Our approach to pattern-based sparsity naturally integrates into compiler optimization for efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is prone to bias from historical events affecting the groups differently. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may reduce bias. We explore this phenomenon through simulation studies. We examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach that leverages the rise in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For this analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we created a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval reflecting substantial adverse effects, no effect, and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to evaluate their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (VPCs), which involve: (1) generating multiple reproductions of the original study by simulating from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with that of the original study. This method is a generic and straightforward approach generally. Here, we focus on applying this method to time-to-event data, specifically addressing the case when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Presented are novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system through sequential schemes. We explore how similar protocols, utilizing repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence according to Zeno physics, (ii) analytically predict the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements, and (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions guiding the designed quantum sensor. Achieving these tasks will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, advancing quantum science and technologies.

I can't think of anyone who has just one interest in life and that's all they want to do forever. Around 15 percent of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" fits with this ethos where people put together various endeavors to make a living. The word "side hustle" has its roots in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they used "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work as well. A side hustle is different from a second job; the latter is about necessity.

Two twin domes reflect two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other is crafted from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One imposes on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other by nature itself. Michelangelo once said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free, and the chisel was his only tool. Yet, living things are not chiseled; they grow. In our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information necessary for cellular function and replication. Tools also have consequences. Since the industrial revolution, the realm of design has been dominated by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people suggest that if you get nervous onstage, you should picture the audience naked? It's supposed to make you feel better. But I was thinking — imagining everyone naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. We're really working hard to move past that kind of mindset, so we need a new way to handle stage nerves. I realized I'd like to look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out. If I had more eyeballs, we'd all be more comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." This is often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, although there's doubt about its origins. What I'm interested in, though, is whether it's true. It's clearly applicable when emailing at the dinner table, texting while driving, or possibly even live-tweeting a TED Talk. However, I'd argue that for certain activities, doing two or even more things simultaneously is precisely what we should strive for. Consider Albert Einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers. His ability to think on multiple fronts shows how multitasking in creative pursuits can be beneficial.

I know this may sound strange, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and during my childhood, he taught me how things worked. We built projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. One day, when I was about 10 years old, he came home and, at the dinner table, announced that our next project would be to build a robot.

Sustainability involves the what, where, and how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices and understand how I impact them. I want to understand how they impact me, why they fish, and how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding this helps us shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows us to celebrate the seafood we are fortunate to eat. So what do we call this? I think we call it restorative seafood. While sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative involves the ability to replenish and progress.

The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of Charles Dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so special? Dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These elements captivated his audience. Initially, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.

I would like to tell you about the future of money, beginning with a fascinating story from the early 1900s involving a culture in Micronesia known as the Yap. The Yap's form of currency is truly intriguing. They used limestone discs called rai stones. Interestingly, the Yap did not exchange these stones as we do with coins, because rai stones could be enormous. The largest one weighs about four tons and measures 12 feet across. Instead, the Yap simply tracked ownership of portions of each stone. There's a tale of sailors transporting a stone across the ocean when it fell into the sea after encountering difficulties.

You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist you’re innocent, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession or risk public hanging? This was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts between February 1692 and May 1693. They were victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated. Battles with Native American neighbors and French settlers were commonplace.

Currently, there are hundreds of thousands on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there are not nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine under development. While printing complex organs is not yet possible, simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange, are already within reach. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.

On October 4, 1957, the world witnessed a groundbreaking event as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the first artificial satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, less than two feet in diameter, initiated a space race between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. that would persist for eighteen years and evolve the world significantly. However, Sputnik was not the first human-made object to reach space. That title belongs to the V-2 rocket, used by Germany for missile attacks against Allied cities in the final years of World War II. Although not very effective, both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. acquired the technology and scientists after the war, propelling their own projects forward.

Menstruation—a simple word describing a natural biological process—has been weighed down by centuries of stigma, transforming it into a topic most of us only speak about in whispers. But why? As I speak to you now, more than 800 million women worldwide are experiencing their period. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject. From my experience and that of the women around me, I can tell you it's exhausting. It's exhausting to discreetly take out a pad, hide it in your pocket during class, and rush to the washroom. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings, pretending to be normal while suffering intense cramps.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of Canada's boreal forest, the largest and most intact forest in the world. It spans across northern Canada, including Labrador, where it hosts the largest remaining wild caribou herd: the George River caribou herd, numbering around 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, during my visit, I couldn't spot any, but antlers serve as proof. The boreal forest is blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands, which are globally one of the most endangered ecosystems. These critical ecosystems clean air and water, sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and are home to a vast diversity of species.

In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept among a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped during a snowstorm, and spent hours in conversation around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt famously cherished the outdoors, but Muir's invitation had a purpose beyond leisure: Yosemite was under threat. Although it became protected land in 1864, the valley faced potential overdevelopment in 1903. It lay at the center of a long-standing struggle to designate land for both preservation and public enjoyment—two objectives easier in theory than practice. The conflict over Yosemite began with the 1849 Gold Rush, as miners surged westward in search of riches in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

Imagine if you could connect your brain to a machine that would provide ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If given the option to choose such an existence, would you take it? This is the question posed by philosopher Robert Nozick in his thought experiment called the Experience Machine. The experiment invites us to consider a world where scientists have created a machine that simulates real life, ensuring experiences of only pleasure and no pain. The catch? You must permanently leave reality behind, though you'll barely notice the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality, with life's natural ups and downs replaced by an endless series of highs. Tempting, isn't it?

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon participates in a natural cycle, present in living things, soil, oceans, the atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When organisms die, much of their stored carbon eventually returns to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb it. Over millions of years, some carbon from ancient trees and sea life becomes rock, while some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rocks. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, also release this prehistoric carbon. Today, humans emit around 60 times more carbon than all the planet's volcanoes combined each year.

Even nature's most unappealing creatures possess important secrets, but who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches approaching them? One of the key differences between natural and human technologies is robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex and unfamiliar environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize while running over rough terrain. When we attached a jet pack to them or exposed them to disturbances like an earthquake, we found their finely tuned legs enabled them to self-stabilize without engaging their brainpower. They can move over complex terrains such as grass with ease, remaining undisturbed. We discovered a behavior where, due to their shape, they automatically roll to their side to navigate this artificial test bit of grass. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure.

What is a parent? It's not an easy question. Today, with adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate mothers, many parents face complex decisions. Should we tell our child about the sperm donation?
